sections.title: Income Streams
sections.content: Rental property returns come from cash flow, loan amortization, tax benefits, and appreciation. Cash flow is the rent left after operating expenses and debt service. Even break-even cash flow can be attractive when rents and property values rise over time.

points.title: Single-Family & Small Multifamily
points.description: Easier to finance, often managed by the owner, and good for first-time investors.

points.title: Commercial & Large Multifamily
points.description: Valued based on net operating income; often require experienced teams and different financing.

points.title: Passive Vehicles
points.description: REITs, syndications, and crowdfunding platforms offer diversification without landlording duties.

sections.title: Use Leverage Deliberately
sections.content: Financing magnifies both gains and losses. Make sure rents cover principal, interest, taxes, insurance, and maintenance with a cushion for vacancies.

sections.title: Return Metrics
sections.content: Cap rate, cash-on-cash return, and internal rate of return (IRR) each tell a story. Cap rate shows how much the property earns before financing; cash-on-cash focuses on the equity you invest; IRR weighs cash flows over time. Compare multiple metrics before committing capital.

sections.title: First Deal Prep
steps: Define your investment goal: cash flow, appreciation, or diversification.
Research local rents and price trends using MLS data or rental platforms.
List the financing options available to you (conventional, portfolio loans, HELOC).
Interview two property managers to understand operating costs and tenant screening.
Run quick math on three properties to compare cap rate and cash-on-cash return.

sections.title: Stay Data Driven
sections.content: Track each prospective property in a spreadsheet so emotion never overrides the numbers.
